p.hi: Velocity of polymer translocation through a pore

body.p: Ding Kejian, Zhan Furu, Cai Dongqin, Yu Zengliang
Abstract

We theoretically study the translocation time and the mean velocity of a long polymer threading a long nanopore on an external electric field. Theoretical method, which explicitly takes into account the nucleation theory, is presented based on the built polymer expanded model. We overcame the previous theory‚Äôs defect which did not consider the real length of the pore. The present model implies that the length scale of a pore plays a very important role in the process of polymer translocation. Our calculation results are in agreement with those of previous experiments. Translocation of polymers across a narrow pore is ubiquitous in biology. Examples include the motion of DNA and RNA molecules across nuclear pores, the injection of viral DNA into a host cell, gene swapping through bacterial pili, DNA packaging into viral capsids, translocation of protein from cis to trans side of a membrane through channels, and involvement of the motion of biopolymers across membranes 123. Alpha-hemolysin, which effectively creates an aqueous nanopore across a lipid membrane, can serve as a model system to study the dynamics of poly- mer translocation. So the mechanisms of polymer translocation have recently been getting great attention in numerous experimental studies4567891011. All of these are helpful to understand the basic biological process and even develop a faster method of DNA sequencing.

The problem of chain molecule threading through a membrane is a complicated phenomenon. At present, most theoretical models suppose that the polymer chain is made of ùëÅNN monomers in order to explain these experimental findings, which provide useful insights for understanding the basic features of a polymer threading membrane. W. Sung and P.J. Park utilized the Fokker-Plank equation to study the Gaussian chain translocation dynamics through a pore embedded in a flat membrane where the monomer friction across the pore is proportional to the length scaling of the polymer 1213141516. M. Muthukumar dealt this process with nucleation theory 2021. G.F. Oster group used modified one-dimensional drift diffusion equation to build a Brownian ratchet mechanism for protein translocation Lubensky and Nelson also studied one-dimensional drift diffusion equations incorporating a simple model of mono- mer-pore interaction 22. E.A. Di Marzio studied thermo- dynamic phase transitions for an isolated polymer molecule in the limitation of infinite molecular weight 232425. Pu. Tian carried out Brownian dynamics simulation study of the translocation of single polymer chain across a nanopore 26. C.-M. Chen used off-lattice Monte-Carlo simula- tions to study the driven translocation dynamics of a polynucleotide chain through a nanopore 27. A. Matsuy- ama theoretically studied the phase transitions of a poly- mer escaping from a pore based on the Flory theory of the coil-globule transitions of a single polymer chain282930 Ambjo√Ç¬®rnsson et al. 31 took into account the nano- pore length and studied both the polymer entrance into the pore and the translocation process. K.L. Sebastian viewed the polymer translocation as the motion of a kink, which travelled in the direction opposite to polymer transport 32. And S. Chern‚Äôs three-dimensional model illustrated that it is indeed impossible to capture many essential features of the translocation process by using an appropriate one-dimensional model 33. And Y.J. Xie 34 used metropolis molecular dynamics simulation 3536 combined with the bond-fluctuation method to study the dynamics process of single DNA chain through an entropic trapping channel driven by an electric force. In this paper, we overcame the previous models‚Äô defect which employed the classic theory without considering the realistic length of the pore 3171830 in order to study the threading of polymer through a pore imbedded in a membrane on external electric field. Based on our polymer expanded model 37, we numerically calculated the overall time of polymer translocation and the velocity of chain through a pore, which is agreement with the previous result 5.
Materials and methods

Suppose a single long polymer with ùëÅNN monomers (each of size a) moves from region I to region III through a membrane pore of length annotatedsubscriptùëô0absentùëõùëél0(=n‚Å¢a)l_{0}(=na) and diameter ùê∑DD, as shown in . ùëéaa is the length of each monomer. In realistic experiments 5, ùëésubscriptùëõ0a,n0a,n_{0} are equal to 4 and 12 ÃäAAÃä\mathring{\mathrm{A}}, respectively. The monomer segments can be divided into region I, II, and III. The free energy of polymer can be derived from the classic nucleation theory 18.

Under the experimental condition, we suppose that the monomer cannot return when it enters into the pore in the external electric field. We simply assume that the interaction between the polymer and the pore can be ignored and chemical potential inside the pore is uniform. Let the chemical potential of the monomer in region I, II, and III be subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2œµ1,œµ2\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}, and subscriptitalic-œµ3œµ3,\epsilon_{3}, respectively (see ). In this paper, the process of translocation is assumed to start as soon as the leading monomer enters the pore and to end when the end of monomer leaves the pore. The whole process can be divided into process I, process II, and process III (see ). We also assume the length of polymer to be much larger than the pore‚Äôs, that is, ùëÅsubscriptùëõ0N>n0.N>n_{0}.
Consider the free energy associated with a translocation of a polymer of ùëÅNN monomer from region I to III. The free energy of the polymer chain can be expressed by

ùêπsubscriptùêπùêºsubscriptùêπùêºùêºsubscriptùêπùêºùêºùêºF=FI+FI‚Å¢I+FI‚Å¢I‚Å¢IF=F_{I}+F_{I}I+F_{I}II, where subscriptùêπùêºsubscriptùêπùêºùêºFI,FI‚Å¢IF_{I},F_{I}I, and subscriptùêπùêºùêºùêºFI‚Å¢I‚Å¢IF_{I}II are free energies of the polymer on region I, II, and III, respectively. Based on the partition function 3 and our analysis, the overall free energy of polymer is given by

The first term is the entropic contribution due to the ùëÅùëõ(N-n)(N-n) free monomers in region I. The second represents the energy gained by moving ùëõnn monomers into the pore, including the effect of the external field and chemical changes. superscriptùõΩ1subscriptùëòBùëáŒ≤-1=kB‚Å¢T\beta^{-1}=k_{\mathrm{B}}T, where subscriptùëòBkBk_{\mathrm{B}} is the Boltzmann constant and ùëáTT is absolute temperature. superscriptsubscriptùõæ1‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùõæ2‚Ä≤Œ≥1‚Ä≤‚Å¢Œ≥2‚Ä≤\gamma_{1}^{\prime}\gamma_{2}^{\prime}, the parameter describing the properties of end- anchored polymer chain in region I, III, is equal to 0.5, 0.69, and 1 for Gaussian, self-avoiding, and rod-like chains, respectively

formulae-sequenceŒîsubscriptitalic-œµ21subscriptitalic-œµ2subscriptitalic-œµ1Œîsubscriptitalic-œµ31subscriptitalic-œµ3subscriptitalic-œµ1Œî‚Å¢œµ21=œµ2-œµ1,Œî‚Å¢œµ31=œµ3-œµ1\Delta\epsilon_{21}=\epsilon_{2}-\epsilon_{1},\Delta\epsilon_{31}=\epsilon_{3}% -\epsilon_{1}, and Œîsubscriptitalic-œµ32subscriptitalic-œµ3subscriptitalic-œµ2Œî‚Å¢œµ32=œµ3-œµ2\Delta\epsilon_{32}=\epsilon_{3}-\epsilon_{2} are the chemical potential difference per monomer that will depend on the type of monomer. Seen from ()() , ùêπFF exhibits a free energy barrier of the polymer, which depends on the conformational statistics of polymer chain and the values of the chemical potential subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2œµ1,œµ2\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}, and subscriptitalic-œµ3œµ3.\epsilon_{3}.

The overall free energy is not a continuous function for the parameter ùëõnn, the result is shown in with our assumption: formulae-sequenceùëÅ100subscriptùëõ012N=100,n0=12N=100,n_{0}=12 for free energy. When formulae-sequenceŒîsubscriptitalic-œµ21Œîsubscriptitalic-œµ21Œîsubscriptitalic-œµ210superscriptsubscriptùõæ1‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùõæ2‚Ä≤0.5Œî‚Å¢œµ21=Œî‚Å¢œµ21=Œî‚Å¢œµ21=0,Œ≥1‚Ä≤=Œ≥2‚Ä≤=0.5\Delta\epsilon_{21}=\Delta\epsilon_{21}=\Delta\epsilon_{21}=0,\gamma_{1}^{% \prime}=\gamma_{2}^{\prime}=0.5, the free energy is symmetric in the whole polymer translocation process, see . But, the barrier becomes asymmetric if Œîitalic-œµ0Œî‚Å¢œµ‚â†0\Delta\epsilon\neq 0. The chemical potential difference is crucial for determining the tendencies of polymer free energy. This is illustrated in . When the leading monomer reaches the region III and the end of monomer escapes from the region I, the free energy of polymer has a transition, which illustrates that the structure of polymer has undergone a large transformation.

It is necessary for us to evaluate the mean translocation time from the previous experiments 4567891011. Following the nucleation theory 38, the transport of the polymer across the nanopore can be described by a Master equation 17 number of

where subscriptùëÉùëõùëñùë°Pn‚Å¢(i,t)P_{n}(i,\ t) is the probability of emerging a ‚Äúcore‚Äù of ùëõnn segments in region i=I, II or III at time formulae-sequenceùë°subscriptùëòùëõt.knt.k_{n} is the rate constant associated with the 10- cal friction in transferring one monomer through the hole so that a nucleus of ùëõnn monomers grows into ùëõ1n+1n+1 monomers, and superscriptsubscriptùëòùëõ‚Ä≤kn‚Ä≤k_{n}^{\prime} is the rate constant of removing one monomer from the ùëõnn monomers. Here, we assume that the rate constant subscriptùëòùëõknk_{n} is independent of ùëõnn and can be indicated by the ratchet potential arising from the details of the pore. Following the Fokker- Planck Equation [H. Riskin, The Fokker-Planck Equation (Springer-Ver- lag, Berlin, 1984)] and Smoluchovskii equation 39, therefore, we obtain,

where the first term is polymer drift contribution. When the first term in this (11) dominates the problem, the mean translocation time ùúèœÑ\tau can be driven as a sum of mean first-passage times in each region, that is, formulae-sequenceùúèsubscriptùúèIsubscriptùúèIIsubscriptùúèIIIsubscriptùúèIsubscriptùúèIIœÑ=œÑI+œÑII+œÑIII.œÑI,œÑII\tau=\tau_{\mathrm{I}}+\tau_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}}+\tau_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}% \mathrm{I}}.\tau_{\mathrm{I}},\tau_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}}, and subscriptùúèIIIœÑIII\tau_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}} are mean first-passage times in region I, II, and III, respectively. The translocation time can be expressed by

m:math.alttext: \begin{split}\displaystyle\tau=K_{0}\int_{0}^{n_{0}}\mathrm{d}m\exp(\beta F_{m% ,\mathrm{I}})\int_{0}^{m}\mathrm{d}n\exp(-\beta F_{n,\mathrm{I}})+K_{0}\int_{n% _{0}}^{N}\mathrm{d}m\exp(\beta F_{m,\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}})\\ \displaystyle\times\int_{0}^{m}\mathrm{d}n\exp(-\beta F_{n,\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I% }})+K_{0}\int_{N}^{N+n_{0}}\mathrm{d}m\exp(\beta F_{m,\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}% \mathrm{I}})\int_{0}^{m}\mathrm{d}n\exp(-\beta F_{n,\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}% \mathrm{I}}).\end{split}

m:semantics.m:annotation: \begin{split}\displaystyle\tau=K_{0}\int_{0}^{n_{0}}\mathrm{d}m\exp(\beta F_{m% ,\mathrm{I}})\int_{0}^{m}\mathrm{d}n\exp(-\beta F_{n,\mathrm{I}})+K_{0}\int_{n% _{0}}^{N}\mathrm{d}m\exp(\beta F_{m,\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}})\\ \displaystyle\times\int_{0}^{m}\mathrm{d}n\exp(-\beta F_{n,\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I% }})+K_{0}\int_{N}^{N+n_{0}}\mathrm{d}m\exp(\beta F_{m,\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}% \mathrm{I}})\int_{0}^{m}\mathrm{d}n\exp(-\beta F_{n,\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}% \mathrm{I}}).\end{split}

body.p: Here, we assume that fragmentssubscriptùëòùëósuperscriptsubscriptùêæ01fragments(iI,II,III)kj=K0-1(i=I,II,III)k_{j}=K_{0}^{-1}(i=\mathrm{I},\ \mathrm{I}\mathrm{I},\ \mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}% \mathrm{I}) is taken to be a nonuniversal constant independent ùëÅNN. As clearly seen from the Ref. 1718, the potential chemical difference controls the polymer translocation time ùúèœÑ.\tau.

For simplicity, if the chemical potential gradient is absent, that is, Œîsubscriptitalic-œµ21Œîsubscriptitalic-œµ31Œîsubscriptitalic-œµ320Œî‚Å¢œµ21=Œî‚Å¢œµ31=Œî‚Å¢œµ32=0\Delta\epsilon_{21}=\Delta\epsilon_{31}=\Delta\epsilon_{32}=0, the exact expression of the translocation time annotatedùúèabsentsubscriptùúèIsubscriptùúèIIsubscriptùúèIIIœÑ(=œÑI+œÑII+œÑIII)\tau(=\tau_{\mathrm{I}}+\tau_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}}+\tau_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}% \mathrm{I}}) can be obtained from:

subscriptùêæ0superscriptùëÅsubscriptùëõ022superscriptsubscriptùõæ2‚Ä≤delimited-[]1superscriptùëÅùëÅsubscriptùëõ0superscriptsubscriptùõæ2‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùõæ2‚Ä≤1superscriptùëÅùëÅsubscriptùëõ022+K0‚Å¢(N+n0)22-Œ≥2‚Ä≤‚Å¢[1-(NN+n0)Œ≥2‚Ä≤Œ≥2‚Ä≤-1-(NN+n0)22]+\displaystyle\frac{K_{0}(N+n_{0})^{2}}{2-\gamma_{2}^{\prime}}[\frac{1-(\frac{% N}{N+n_{0}})^{\gamma_{2}^{\prime}}}{\gamma_{2}^{\prime}}-\frac{1-(\frac{N}{N+n% _{0}})^{2}}{2}].

Here, ùëéaa is a constant depending on superscriptsubscriptùõæ1‚Ä≤Œ≥1‚Ä≤\gamma_{1}^{\prime} and superscriptsubscriptùõæ2‚Ä≤Œ≥2‚Ä≤\gamma_{2}^{\prime}, which is equal to 0.5 for the special case of superscriptsubscriptùõæ1‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùõæ2‚Ä≤0.5Œ≥1‚Ä≤=Œ≥2‚Ä≤=0.5\gamma_{1}^{\prime}=\gamma_{2}^{\prime}=0.5. From this equation, we know that the polymer entering the long pore is more difficult than that entering the short pore and the longer the polymer is, the shorter the translocation time of process III is, which are in agreement with the previous result 40. Sup- posing the length of translocated pore is variable for a given polymer. illustrates the translocation time against the pore length ùëõnn under this condition. We can draw a conclusion that the length of the pore deter- mines the polymer translocation process to some degree.

Under the experimental condition, we assume that the polymer is to start as soon as the leading monomer of the polymer enters the pore and to end when the end monomer escapes the pore. If we consider that the translocation time was measured only when a current passing through the pore dropped to a level below superscript6500650/065^{0}/0 of an open channel current in the experiments of Meller et al. 5 So, based on considering the translocation process starting when superscript3500350/035^{0}/0 of the polymer entered into the pore and ending when only superscript3500350/035^{0}/0 of the polymer was left in the pore, the whole translocation time can be expressed by being based on the polymer expansion model 37

ùúèsuperscriptùõΩ10.30subscriptùëõ0subscriptùëòIŒîsubscriptitalic-œµ21ùëÅsubscriptùëòIIŒîsubscriptitalic-œµ310.30subscriptùëõ0subscriptùëòIIIŒîsubscriptitalic-œµ32œÑ=Œ≤-1‚Å¢(0.30‚Å¢n0kI‚Å¢|Œî‚Å¢œµ21|+NkII‚Å¢|Œî‚Å¢œµ31|+0.30‚Å¢n0kIII‚Å¢|Œî‚Å¢œµ32|)\displaystyle\tau=\beta^{-1}(\frac{0.30n_{0}}{k_{\mathrm{I}}|\Delta\epsilon_{2% 1}|}+\frac{N}{k_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}}|\Delta\epsilon_{31}|}+\frac{0.30n_{0}}{% k_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}}|\Delta\epsilon_{32}|}) , ùëÅsubscriptùëõ0(N>n0)(N>n_{0})Here, we use 0.30 subscriptùëõ0ùëÅO.3subscriptùëõ0n0,N+O‚Å¢.3‚Å¢n0n_{0},N+\mathrm{O}.3n_{0} instead subscriptùëõ0n0n_{0} and ùëÅùëõN+nN+n, respectively. So the polymer translocation velocity is given by

¬Øùë£ùëÅ0.30subscriptùëõ0ùëéùõΩsuperscript0.30subscriptùëõ0subscriptùëòIŒîsubscriptitalic-œµ21ùëÅsubscriptùëòIIŒîsubscriptitalic-œµ310.30subscriptùëõ0subscriptùëòIIIŒîsubscriptitalic-œµ321v¬Ø=(N+0.30‚Å¢n0)‚Å¢a‚Å¢Œ≤‚Å¢(0.30‚Å¢n0kI‚Å¢|Œî‚Å¢œµ21|+NkII‚Å¢|Œî‚Å¢œµ31|+0.30‚Å¢n0kIII‚Å¢|Œî‚Å¢œµ32|)-1\displaystyle\overline{v}=(N+0.30n_{0})a\beta(\frac{0.30n_{0}}{k_{\mathrm{I}}|% \Delta\epsilon_{21}|}+\frac{N}{k_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}}|\Delta\epsilon_{31}|}+% \frac{0.30n_{0}}{k_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}}|\Delta\epsilon_{32}|})^{-1}.

In order to compare our theoretical predictions with the experimental data 5, we use this equation to fit the experiment data, see the curve (3) in . Curve (2) in is the modified equation picture and curve (1) is the original equation picture, that is, the expanded length of the polymer is ùëÅsubscriptùëõ0N+n0N+n_{0}. We assume that the total length of polymer and pore is 100ùëé100‚Å¢a100a and 12ùëé12‚Å¢a12a, respectively. And the monomer size is given by ùëé4ÃäAa=4‚Å¢AÃäa=4\mathring{\mathrm{A}}. The fitted curve indicates that formulae-sequenceŒîsubscriptitalic-œµ21Œîsubscriptitalic-œµ322.9superscriptùõΩ1formulae-sequenceŒîsubscriptitalic-œµ315.8superscriptùõΩ1subscriptùëòIsubscriptùëòIII2.2superscript107ùúássubscriptùëòII1.58superscript104ùúásŒî‚Å¢œµ21=Œî‚Å¢œµ32=2.9‚Å¢Œ≤-1,Œî‚Å¢œµ31=5.8‚Å¢Œ≤-1,kI=kIII=2.2√ó107‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢s,kII=1.58√ó104‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢s\Delta\epsilon_{21}=\Delta\epsilon_{32}=2.9\beta^{-1},\Delta\epsilon_{31}=5.8% \beta^{-1},k_{\mathrm{I}}=k_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}}=2.2\times 10^{7}% \mu\mathrm{s},k_{\mathrm{I}\mathrm{I}}=1.58\times 10^{4}\mu\mathrm{s}. This predicts that for long poly- mer, the translocation velocity approaches a constant value and the veloc- ity increases remarkably with decreasing polymer length, which is in excellent qualitative and quantitative agreement with experiments when- ever for modified model and original model.
Discussion

In this paper, a simple model of polymer threading through a long pore was presented on the external electric fields. We have derived explicit expression for the translo- cation time and the mean velocity of polymer translocation across a pore without considering the interaction between the polymer and the pore and the fluctuation of the chemical potential inside the pore. Both the length scaling of polymer and pore are crucial factors for dynamics of polymer translocation. The original theoretical model and modified theoretical model predict the mean velocity of polymer translocation for experimental condition. It is found that short polymers move faster than long polymers whose velocity is nearly constant, which is in excellent agreement with previous experiments results qualitatively and quantitatively.

We have provided a reasonable model for polymer translocation, but there are many factors that have not been considered in this paper, such as interaction between the polymer and the pore, temperature of the solvent, electrostatic interaction, and realistic geometry of pore. We hope that our results encourage further experimental and analytical studies of forced translocation including these factors. In particular, how to control the polymer velocity is helpful to develop new DNA sequencing methods.
Acknowledgments

We thank our research group for helpful discussion. This work was supported by the Innovation project of the Chinese Academy of Sciences under Grant No. KSCX2-SW-324, and the National Science Fund for Dis- tinguished Young Scholars under Grant No. 10225526.
